fields.description:
h3. Summary


h3. Environment
* Bitbucket Server installed using internal database
* MS SQL installed to use named instances


h3. Problem
In the [Supported platforms|https://confluence.atlassian.com/display/BitbucketServer/Supported+platforms] page full support for SQL Server but due to [BSERV-3759|https://jira.atlassian.com/browse/BSERV-3759] is not possible to migrate from the internal database to a named instance of SQL Server using the UI procedure.


h3. Proposed Solution
Include a warning section in [Supported platforms|https://confluence.atlassian.com/display/BitbucketServer/Supported+platforms]  to warn customers about the missing compatibility. 

Also include a link to [Connecting to named instances in SQL Server from Stash|https://confluence.atlassian.com/display/STASHKB/Connecting+to+named+instances+in+SQL+Server+from+Stash] warn customers on strategies to migrate to a named instance of SQL Server in case needed.


h3. Notes
In case the customer is using Stash and Backup Client 2.0.x there would be an extra problem in the migration due to [BSERV-8280|https://jira.atlassian.com/browse/BSERV-8280].
fields.summary: Support for SQL Server named instances

h1. Reproduce the problem:
* Using Disk Management split the drive into two partition
* Mount the Home Directory directly on B:\ (as an example)
* Launch BBS and it should start correctly 
* Start the backup using BBSBC 2.0.1 (Have not tested previous versions) and it fails with the below trace

Note that this is not a network mapped drive - it is all on the same HD.

The workaround is to place the home directory into a directory of that drive like B:\bitbucket-home and the backup will work perfectly fine after that.

fields.description: It should be possible to manage project \ repositories permissions in bulk.
fields.summary: Bulk project permissions

fields.description:
When using Bitbucker with a huge team that is working on different projects, you will receive a lot of incoming pull requests. It's difficult to keep an overview of pull requests you still need to review and pull requests you have reviewed.

In order to improve this functionality, I suggest to introduce a new button on the Pull Request page. Today we have "Accept" or "Decline". It would be nice if we have an in-between status like "Check". This means you don't accept nor decline the pull request, you just wait for further updates. By doing this, the Pull Requests is removed from the inbox until new changes have been added to that pull request.
fields.summary: Introduce a new button on the Pull Request page

fields.description:
Smart Mirroring (available in Data Center) lets remote teams sync git repos to a local server to improve clone and fetch performance.

Git LFS lets teams store large binary files in a way that avoids the performance penalty that comes with storing them directly in Git.

Both are new features that solve slightly different scale problems. This suggestion is for the ability for mirrored repositories to work with Git LFS.

We are interested in hearing use cases from people interested in adopting Smart Mirroring and LFS together. In particular, we expect that people will want everything actively synced to remote mirrors (Git + LFS content), and would like to confirm that this is indeed the case. Please comment below if this is you!

Cheers,
- Roger
Atlassian
fields.summary: Support Git LFS in combination with Smart Mirroring

fields.description:
The 2GB Limit for Bitbucket is a real problem.  I need up to 10GB space and I want to use Bitbucket without setting up a server.

When will this limit increase?
fields.summary: 2GB Limit for Bitbucket

fields.description:
When doing a code review (identified by a pull request) and in the [Diff] view:
I’ve been finding it difficult to scroll the code compare slider to the next change when reviewing changes with several scattered 1-liner mods.
The pale green color identifying where the next change is located can be hard to see and hard to slide the view to.

It would be very helpful to have a button that would take the view to the next change (and another to go back to previous change).
An additional button that would jump back to the very first change would also be helpful since some reviews require an additional pass through the change.
fields.summary: During pull request review [Diff] add buttons for previous/next change

fields.description:
When there are no pull requests, you get a giant "create pull request" button. When there are pull requests you have to click the "..." in the sidebar and hit "create pull request"

It's weird and inconsistent.
fields.summary: when there are active pull requests, pull request page doesn't have an obvious way to create a new pull request
Stash's comments mangle NSString literals and other @-prefixed things (@"foo" is rendered as @foo)

fields.description: You should be abe to copy a diff from stash.  The diff view doesn’t allow you to extract a unified diff to the clipboard. This is useful for quick sharing of a change with other groups outside of my group when debugging.
fields.summary: The diff view doesn’t allow you to extract a unified diff to the clipboard

fields.description:
I don’t know if it’s Safari, slow computers, or my lack of patience, but now on two separate occasions I’ve unapproved a pull request by accident when I mean to approve it.

Sometimes when clicking Approve the first time, there seems to be a lag or lack of response. But clicking it again appears to send two clicks to the server, which spams all the subscribers with “John Approved this pull request” followed by “John UNAPPROVED this pull request”

The UI should probably have a more explicit unapprove UI, like a confirmation click or at least some amount of synchronization where the UI gets locked out for a few seconds or require a refresh to unapprove, or a separate unapprove button.
fields.summary: The UI should probably have a more explicit unapprove UI

fields.description:
*Precondition:*
We require one successful build on our Bamboo Server (5.9.4 build 5919) to merge a pull 
request. 

*Situation:*
In our case we have several Bamboo projects working on the same bitbucket repository and some of them are using plan branches.

*Bug*
If one of the plan branches on Bamboo fails (other build params, merging strategy etc.) and this plan branch is deleted, Bitbucket will still show one build failed. As the plan branch doesnt exist on Bamboo anymore there is no chance to remedy this problem. If you click in Bitbucket on this failed (non-existing) job it will redirect to a Page not found page. Even after closing this pull request and opening a new one it will automatically detect this non-existing failed jobs again, so there is no chance to merge the pull request.
fields.summary: Bitbucket keeps outdated Bamboo build information

fields.description:
When we have many projects it would be great if we could do a fast search to get what we want.
There should be a search box to search projects by name \ key in the projects list screen.
fields.summary: Filter project list
Examples are useful

fields.description:
Whenever I create a branch from JIRA Software (JDOG), I'm sent to BBS and I can select branch type and where to branch from. This is all set correctly: 'Feature' and 'master'. However, BBS used to evaluate these answers and deduct that my branch name should be prefixed with 'issue/'. This now only happens when I click 'Feature' one more time.

Please fix this, I've had to remove + re-add my branch 3 times now, I couldn't find my branch (looking for issue/...) and Bamboo won't pick up my branch for building, as it expects it to start with issue/.

*Reporter*: Dick Wiggers
fields.summary: My branches aren't auto-prefixed with issue/ anymore. I have to manually click 'Feature' branch type.

fields.description:
Hi!

So, I'm pushing tags to Stash using the REST API, and I'm running into a little problem.

Let's say I have a repository with a bunch of commits (see screenshot 1) and I run my script repeatedly to create tags (see screenshot 2). The tags will show in the git log, and appear in the branch/tag dropdown, as well as the "network" plugin we use for branching history visualization, but do *not* appear in the commit history (see screenshot 3.) :(

However, if I then create _another_ tag and push it (see screenshot 4) all the previously created tags will become visible immediately. (see screenshot 5.)

I have also determined that the "magic button" is ONLY a git tag push - just pushing any old commit to the repository will not refresh the tags the same way.

I couldn't find any similar bugs in your jira db... so... um... sorry if this is a duplicate and/or has been fixed in a newer version.
fields.summary: Git tags created in API not visible until _after_ another tag is pushed from a git client.

fields.description:
We had been using Stash for a long time with LDAP integration. Everything was good.
Where a user authenticated with LDAP (AD) credentials Stash added it into "stash-users" group specified in "Default Group Memberships" field of LDAP Settings (LDAP Permissions section).
This group has Global Permission "Bitbucket User". 
So any user authenticated via LDAP could use Stash. It was nice.

Now we have migrated onto Bitbucket 4.2 and this doesn't work anymore: a user authenticated but isn't added into the group. So he/she sees "You do not have permission to access Bitbucket" error. We have manually add him/her into that group. 
Needless to say how troublesome it is.
fields.summary: BitBucket 4 with LDAP integration does not add new users into "Default Group Memberships" group anymore

fields.description:
Commit comments where introduced in the release v2.11. In my opinion it is a good feature to  
start discussions and get feedback before a Pull Request is opened. When a Pull Request is created, comments added in the Diff tab and/or file level are added to the Overview tab. I think that it would be nice to add comments included in commits in the Overview as well, so every single comment related to the code that is going to be reviewed can be checked from the same place, the overview tab and the reviewer doesn't have to move to the commit tab. I think that It would be useful for reviewers to have all this information in the same place helping them to save time when reviewing code.
fields.summary: Show Bitbucket Commit comments at Pull Request Overview

fields.description:
When I create a branch from a ticket in JIRA it gives me the option to choose what branch to base the new branch off of. We follow the workflow where normally you're branching from a branch and then merging back into that branch. This applies even for cherry picks where you're moving from one master branch to another (or from master to a release branch or something like that.)

In any case, since I've already specified where the branch should originate; and the typical workflow is to merge back into that branch, it's unexpected that bamboo / bitbucket would choose to create the PR to go back into the default branch.

My suggestion is to have the PR by default merge back into its immediate parent; and maybe, if that differs from the default branch to put a ! warning, or a model dialog asking if that's what you want to do.
fields.summary: Default merge branch for PR should be the immediate parent branch (or maybe an option to merge into the default)

fields.description: Backup Client does not properly store datatype for some AO tables.  Some of the columns types in the AO tables are not backed up properly causing MS SQL Server to restore the column type as {{ntext}}.
fields.summary: Backup Client does not properly store schema datatype for some AO tables

fields.description:
Pressing the Merge button in Bitbucket server produces a cryptic permissions error:

`Permission problems. You are not allowed to execute the requested JIRA Rest action`

The solution seems to be to go back to the pull request overview page, click on the issue number to bring up the ticket details popup, then follow the link to re-authenticate with JIRA via oAuth, then go back to the pull request and try the merge button again....

It's workable but not very intuitive and feels like a bug!
fields.summary: Permissions error when trying to merge a PR from BSERV

fields.description:
I have the "Prevent changes without a pull request" option ticked, so no users can push to (e.g.) {{master}}. However all users (who have write access) can merge a pull request into this branch (once approved).

I'd like to be able to control who can merge a pull request, and limit this to a specific set of users (which won't necessarily be the same as the set of users who have full write access to that branch).

Note I'm mainly thinking about pull requests within a repo (as we use pull requests to enforce reviews), but this could apply to pull requests from a fork too.
fields.summary: Limit who can merge a pull request on a particular branch

fields.description:
I have two bitbucket accounts. One I use at work with my work email address and one I use for my non-work related projects. When I am working on work related projects and push a commit, it shows up using my other account even though that account doesn't have access to those repos. 

I assume it has something to do with that fact that I access both bitbucket accounts on the same machine from the command line so it likely uses the same ssh certificate, but its going to cause me issues and seems like a security problem to our IT department.
fields.summary: wrong account gets reported to bitbucket

fields.description:
The branch name at the top of pull requests is a little to short for the format of all fix branches: eng/PR-12345678 (where that’s the radar # being fixed on this branch)

If this is configurable, could we make it bigger and how? If it’s not, could we ask for it to be made configurable?
fields.summary: Source branch name is truncated too aggressively in pull request header

fields.description:
h3. Summary
Restoring a backup of Stash (any 2.x or 3.x) version using the Bitbucket Server Backup Client 2.0+ recreates some columns with an incorrect type. The incorrect column types are created on restore _regardless of the database_ Stash was using when the backup was taken, and regardless of whether Stash was backed up with the Stash Backup Client (1.x) or the Bitbucket Server Backup Client (2.x). The important detail is that the _restore_ is done with the Bitbucket Server Backup Client (2.x).

h3. Steps to Reproduce
# [Backup a Stash instance|https://confluence.atlassian.com/bitbucketserver/using-the-bitbucket-server-backup-client-776640064.html#UsingtheBitbucketServerBackupClient-BackingupBitbucketServerusingtheclient] with _any_ backup client
# [Restore the backup|https://confluence.atlassian.com/bitbucketserver/using-the-bitbucket-server-backup-client-776640064.html#UsingtheBitbucketServerBackupClient-RestoringBitbucketServertouseanewlycreatedDB] with [the latest backup client|https://marketplace.atlassian.com/plugins/com.atlassian.stash.backup.client/server/overview]

h3. Expected Results
When checking the {{AO_02A6C0_REJECTED_REF}} table in the restored database, it should look like this:
!https://monosnap.com/file/duhPXKYC8N8XHzqhIqSel3lO4Cv5JC.png|height=300!

h3. Actual Results
{{REF_ID}} and {{REF_DISPLAY_ID}} are created with the {{ntext}} instead of {{varchar(767)}} (on SQL Server; on other databases they will be created as that DBMS's {{CLOB}} type).
!https://monosnap.com/file/n2jUwy6zym2fGakaVjAwOqyLl1dFr2.png|height=300!

The exception below is thrown and logged in the {{atlassian-bitbucket.log}} or {{atlassian-stash.log}} file of an instance experiencing this issue:
{noformat}
2015-12-16 15:36:27,956 ERROR [http-nio-7990-exec-1] jdoe @1RR82X8x936x444x0 d15xgs 0.0.0.0 "GET /rest/sync/latest/projects/KEY/repos/slug HTTP/1.1" c.a.s.i.r.e.DefaultUnhandledExceptionMapperHelper Unhandled exception while processing REST request: "GET /rest/sync/latest/projects/KEY/repos/slug HTTP/1.1"
com.atlassian.activeobjects.internal.ActiveObjectsInitException: bundle [com.atlassian.bitbucket.server.bitbucket-repository-ref-sync]
Caused by: com.atlassian.activeobjects.internal.ActiveObjectsSqlException: There was a SQL exception thrown by the Active Objects library:
Database:
	- name:Microsoft SQL Server
	- version:10.50.1600
	- minor version:50
	- major version:10
Driver:
	- name:Microsoft JDBC Driver 4.2 for SQL Server
	- version:4.2.6420.100

com.microsoft.sqlserver.jdbc.SQLServerException: Argument data type ntext is invalid for argument 1 of len function.
{noformat}

This error indicates fork syncing cannot function because its database schema is incorrect.
 
h3.Workaround

We've identified that the issue occurs on the ActiveObjects library we ship with our client. 

We've tested it and restoring a backup with Stash Backup Client 1.9.1 (which contains ActiveObjects 0.28 as opposed to 0.29 on the latest version) works successfully.

There are a few alternatives:
- *Alternative 1 (Stash 3.11 or earlier ONLY):*
-- Backup and restore with a backup/restore client that contains an older version of the Active objects. In order to check that, you should check the following directory of your unzipped backup client:
{noformat}
$ ls -ltra stash-backup-client-1.9.1/lib | grep active
-rw-rw-r--@   1 tbomfim  staff    23717  6 Mar  2015 activeobjects-spi-0.28.1.jar
-rw-rw-r--@   1 tbomfim  staff  2238224  6 Mar  2015 activeobjects-plugin-0.28.1.jar
{noformat}

- *Alternative 2:*
-- use the [DIY backup scripts|https://confluence.atlassian.com/bitbucketserver/using-bitbucket-server-diy-backup-776640056.html] to backup and restore your instance. 

- *Alternative 3:*
-- If the scripts above are intimidating or not an easy solution to be worked on by you (they need to be rewritten as they are written to support PostgreSQL), alternatively you could also simply:
--- Stop Stash
--- Make a cold backup of the {{STASH_HOME}} (i.e. copy the directory to another storing device)
--- Make a cold backup of the database (i.e. with your own database native backup tool)
--- *additional note:* the *Alternative 3* should be enough for you to restore in case the restore fails. It is actually what the DIY backup does but in a more elegant approach by locking your instance and implementing all the steps described on [Advanced - writing your own DIY Backup using the REST APIs|https://confluence.atlassian.com/bitbucketserver/using-bitbucket-server-diy-backup-776640056.html#UsingBitbucketServerDIYBackup-Advanced-writingyourownDIYBackupusingtheRESTAPIs].
fields.summary: Restoring a Stash 3x backup with Backup Client 2+ recreates some columns with the wrong type
Null dates in Active Objects causes the Active Objects framework to save the object

fields.description:
h3. Problem Definition

In order to migrate Stash/Bitbucket server to a different server, customers need to follow the procedure below:

- [Download the Backup/restore client|https://marketplace.atlassian.com/plugins/com.atlassian.stash.backup.client/server/overview]. This is a Java application that has to be run on the same server as where your Stash/Bitbucket server instance is running.
- [Backup your current Bitbucket Server using the client|https://confluence.atlassian.com/bitbucketserver/using-the-bitbucket-server-backup-client-776640064.html#UsingtheBitbucketServerBackupClient-BackingupBitbucketServerusingtheclient] you downloaded above
- Restore the file generated in the operation above into the new server ({{stash-YYYYMMDD-HHMMSS-ID.tar}} file should be inside the {{<backup-tool>/backups}}). Please use the guidelines below:
-- [Restoring Bitbucket Server to use a newly created DB |https://confluence.atlassian.com/bitbucketserver/using-the-bitbucket-server-backup-client-776640064.html#UsingtheBitbucketServerBackupClient-RestoringBitbucketServertouseanewlycreatedDB]

The problem occurs when the restore is completed. If you try to upgrade the current restored {{BITBUCKET_HOME}} by using the installer, the validation done by the installer sees the restore as invalid and shows this message:
{noformat}
The home directory structure could not be recognized. Please choose a valid home directory
{noformat}

h3. Cause

The cause for that is that the installer checks for the existence of the following directories to decide whether or not the home directory is OK to upgrade: "caches", "export", "log", "plugins", "shared", "shared/data", "shared/config", "shared/plugins", "tmp"

However, according to [What is backed up|https://confluence.atlassian.com/bitbucketserver/using-the-bitbucket-server-backup-client-776640064.html#UsingtheBitbucketServerBackupClient-Whatisbackedup], our backup client does not backup "caches", for example.

h3. Suggested Solution

Relax the restriction check on the Upgrade workflow to make it match what we backup with the client by default.
 
h3. Workaround 

As a workaround, customers migrating should:
# Install the binary that is running on the original server pointing to an empty directory, it will start up just like a first installation screen (i.e. it will ask you to enter details of license, etc.)
# If that's achieved, your installation was successful. Please stop your instance at this point.
# Copy the content of the restored directory into the empty {{STASH_HOME}} of this new installation
# Restart the newly installed Stash
# At this stage, an upgrade will be performed. You should be able to see the same content as the old machine on the Stash UI
# [Upgrade your instance to the most recent release|https://confluence.atlassian.com/bitbucketserver/bitbucket-server-upgrade-guide-776640551.html] only once you got the old installation completely functional
fields.summary: Relax directory check on the Upgrade flow of the installer

fields.description:
Git [{{v2.5.0}}|https://github.com/git/git/blob/v2.5.0/Documentation/RelNotes/2.5.0.txt#L106] introduced [{{uploadpack.allowReachableSHA1InWant}}|https://github.com/git/git/blob/v2.5.0/Documentation/config.txt#L2570], which allows fetching any commit from a remote repository as long as that commit is reachable from at least one ref. This can be useful for grabbing smaller subsets of large repositories at specific commits.

Since {{allowReachableSHA1InWant}} only allows access to commits reachable from at least one ref, it's not exposing any commits to which a remote client would not already have access; it just means they can fetch such commits directly, rather than having to fetch a ref (which may include a significant amount of unnecessary data in the resulting pack) and then checkout the desired commit.
fields.summary: Enable uploadpack.allowReachableSHA1InWant

fields.description:
h3. Summary

After configurating Kerberos authentication to a SQL Server database, Bitbucket stops responding after a while and the application freezes.

Upgrading previous versions of Stash (that were running with Kerberos) to Bitbucket Server will cause this issue as well. 

The reason why is that from Stash to Bitbucket, the software that handles the database pool has changed from BoneCP to HikariCP:
- [Stash config properties|https://confluence.atlassian.com/display/STASH0311/Stash+config+properties#Stashconfigproperties-Databasepool]
{quote}
These properties control the database pool. The pool implementation used is BoneCP. Documentation for these settings can be found at: http://jolbox.com/configuration.html 
{quote}
- [Bitbucket Server config properties|https://confluence.atlassian.com/bitbucketserver/bitbucket-server-config-properties-776640155.html#BitbucketServerconfigproperties-Databasepool]
{quote}
These properties control the database pool. The pool implementation used is HikariCP. Documentation for these settings can be found at: https://github.com/brettwooldridge/HikariCP/wiki/Configuration 
To get a feel for how these settings really work in practice, the most relevant classes in HikariCP are:
com.zaxxer.hikari.HikariConfig Holds the configuration for the database pool and has documentation for the available settings.
com.zaxxer.hikari.pool.HikariPool Provides the database pool and manages connections.
com.zaxxer.hikari.util.ConnectionBag Holds references to open connections, whether in-use or idle.
{quote}

*Required fix:*
We need to apply a fix in BBS that makes sure when HikariCP goes to open a connection it uses the webapp's ClassLoader, not the ClassLoader of whatever thread it's acquiring a connection on.

h3. Environment
{panel}
(i) This problem occurs:
- when setting up Bitbucket Server (4.0+) with Kerberos _running on Linux_ with MS-SQL Server as external database or;
- when setting up Bitbucket Server (4.0+) with any database configuration that requires access to a {{com.sun}} class and a plugin requesting a database connection requires the system to open a new one. I.e. BBS connected to an Oracle instance authenticating against an LDAP server.
- Kerberos and LDAP support are both implemented in {{com.sun}} classes, so they both trigger the issue
{panel}

Only mixed-mode authentication is supported on Linux. 

Integrated or Kerberos authentication to SQL Server is only supported on a Windows server.

The {{com.sun}} packages are not available to plugins, which results in the module not being available to {{ActiveObjects}} and causing the error above. On Windows, the Sun packages are not required as the DLL's in the JDBC driver provide everything needed.


h3. Steps to Reproduce
Configure your environment with Kerberos as described on:
- [Connecting Bitbucket Server to SQL Server|https://confluence.atlassian.com/bitbucketserver/connecting-bitbucket-server-to-sql-server-776640385.html#ConnectingBitbucketServertoSQLServer-blaUseIntegratedAuthenticationor'WindowsAuthenticationMode'(Optional)]

h3. Expected Results
Application should work normally.

h3. Actual Results
The following error can be seeing in the {{atlassian-bitbucket.log}}:
{noformat}
Caused by: javax.security.auth.login.LoginException: unable to find LoginModule class: com.sun.security.auth.module.Krb5LoginModule not found from bundle [com.atlassian.bitbucket.server.bitbucket-notification]
{noformat}

Or

{noformat}
Caused by: java.sql.SQLRecoverableException: IO Error: JNDI Package failure javax.naming.NoInitialContextException: Cannot instantiate class: com.sun.jndi.ldap.LdapCtxFactory [Root exception is java.lang.ClassNotFoundException: com.sun.jndi.ldap.LdapCtxFactory not found from bundle [com.atlassian.bitbucket.server.bitbucket-notification]]
{noformat}
 

h3.Workaround

*1- Add a property to {{<BITBUCKET_HOME>/shared/bitbucket.properties}}*

Modify [{{bitbucket.properties}}|https://confluence.atlassian.com/bitbucketserver/bitbucket-server-config-properties-776640155.html] to add the following line:
{noformat}
db.pool.size.idle=${db.pool.size.max}
{noformat}

This will force the pool to open all of the possible connections immediately, which should prevent the unable to find LoginModule class error from happening in plugins.

{panel}
(i) *Restart required*

Note that after adding a property to {{bitbucket.properties}} an application restart is required.
{panel}

*2- Use mixed mode*

If you'd like to stay on Linux, the solution is to allow mixed-mode authentication on the SQL Server and specify a username and password to connect to the database.

Alternatively, a migration to Windows will allow you to use the native DLL's.
fields.summary: Bitbucket 4.0 freezes when running on Linux with MS SQL Server database using Kerberos authentication

fields.description:
h3. Problem Definition
Due to BSERV-7741, we should ship 1.8.0_65 as opposed to 1.8.0_60.

This JRE can cause issues as described on [No subject alternative names|https://confluence.atlassian.com/display/BitbucketServerKB/No+subject+alternative+names+-+LDAP+with+SSL] and BSERV-7741.

h3. Workaround 
If you are hitting the issue described on [No subject alternative names|https://confluence.atlassian.com/display/BitbucketServerKB/No+subject+alternative+names+-+LDAP+with+SSL], a valid workaround for us at the moment consists in:
- Editing {{<BITBUCKET_INSTALL>/bin/setenv.sh}}
- Changing:
{noformat}
#
# Occasionally Atlassian Support may recommend that you set some specific JVM arguments.  You can use this variable
# below to do that.
#
JVM_SUPPORT_RECOMMENDED_ARGS=""
{noformat}
Into:
{noformat}
#
# Occasionally Atlassian Support may recommend that you set some specific JVM arguments.  You can use this variable
# below to do that.
#
JVM_SUPPORT_RECOMMENDED_ARGS="-Djdk.tls.trustNameService=true"
{noformat}
- Restarting your Bitbucket server
fields.summary: Upgrade Bitbucket Embedded JRE to 1.8.0_65 from 1.8.0_60

fields.description:
When a user clicks 'Delete', a lightbox is shown with the default action (executed by simple Enter) being DELETE rather than CANCEL.

We should make it slightly more difficult to remove something: suggest typing "delete" as a confirmation.

fields.description:

fields.description: A fresh Bitbucket Server install is coming pre-populated with a default group named "stash-users". I think this may be confusing, considering it's a fresh install (so I believe it could be "bitbucket-users").

fields.description:
*As a developer*
I would like to have the possibility to copy a pull-request
*so that I*
can deliver the same change to several branches


Our use case is that we have several release branches for a longer time period. The release branches should not in normal cases be merged but there are a number of changes that should go into all release branches.
The copy function should 
# cherry-pick the commits as shown in the commits-tab
# Prompt the user for a new base commit 
  the base commit could be a SHA1 or a drop-down list of existing branches
# create a new branch with 'base commit' + 'cherry-picked commits'
  the branch name could be inherited from the original pull-request, with a suffix
  the branch name could be prompted to the user
# start the pull-request create dialog for the new branch


*BONUS:* The same workflow can be used to provide a "Revert" pull-request function.
fields.summary: Copy (cherry-pick) pull-request

fields.description:
*As a developer*
I would like to have a way to quickly rebase my pull-request by pushing a button
*so that I*
find it easy to ensure I base my changes on the latest in the "to-branch"


Detailed suggestion:
* The rebase should be possible to initiate by pushing a button
* If the rebase fails, inform the user that the rebase has to be performed locally. (Possibly also include what files that were in conflict)
fields.summary: Rebase button for Pull-Requests

fields.description: When a user pushes to a branch that is write protected or requires a pull request (per branch permissions), include instructions in the console output for creating a branch and creating a pull request, as appropriate.
fields.summary: Provide git console instructions for creating a branch and pull request on branch permissions failure

fields.description: Setting excludes for a merge would be useful in cases where you have certain files or directories are unique to a particular branch and you don't want these to change in an automatic merge. If a user selects files or sets exclude paths, any matching files would remain unchanged through the automatic merge process.
fields.summary: Set excludes for merges and automatic merges

fields.description:
At the source code when the scroll bar is placed at top, context option box able to show copy and paste option. When moved to bottom or anywhere in middle the context option box does not show copy and paste option. 

h2. Workaround
Use the keyboard shortcuts cmd/ctrl + c to copy code to the clipboard.

h2. Environment: 
Ubuntu 14.04
Java 8

h2. Expected Result:
To allow the context option box to have copy and paste option throughout the source code from top to bottom.

h2. Actual Result:
Does not have copy and paste option in the context option box.

 
Screenshot:
When scroll bar at top:
 !at top.png|thumbnail! 

When scroll bar not at top:
 !at mid or bot.png|thumbnail!
fields.summary: Mouse context menu (right click) does not containt copy/paste/cut when source view is scrolled

fields.description:
When you click the Create Branch link in Jira, the following parameters are sent to BitBucket:

issueKey
issueType
issueSummary

BitBucket uses the issueKey and the issueSummary to create a default branch name {issueKey}-{issueSummary with spaces replaced with dashes}.

Our standard is to use just the Jira Issue Key. It would be great if this behavior was configurable so I could select something like just {issueKey}.
fields.summary: Allow default branch name to be configurable on the Create Branch integration with Jira
Debug log message indicates "Limit exceeded" after pushing one commit

fields.description:
h3. Summary

The DIY backup script [example|https://bitbucket.org/atlassianlabs/atlassian-bitbucket-diy-backup/src/2d7a3caa04bf846fab2039ce5e4af48f9bb7409b/bitbucket.diy-backup.rsync.sh?at=master&fileviewer=file-view-default] intends to exclude the {{db.*}} files which are held within {{shared/data/}} in the Bitbucket/Stash Home directory. However it lists the exclude as follows missing the {{/shared/}} parent directory off:

{code}
--exclude=/data/db.*
{code}

It is also stated in the [documentation|https://confluence.atlassian.com/bitbucketserver/using-the-bitbucket-server-backup-client-776640064.html#UsingtheBitbucketServerBackupClient-Whatisbackedup] that {{data/db*}} is excluded again omitting the {{shared/}} directory.

h3. Expected Results

The db files are excluded

h3. Actual Results

The db files are not excluded
fields.summary: The exclude for data/db.* is missing the shared parent folder

fields.description:
h3. Problem:
When upgrading Stash 3.x to Bitbucket Server 4.x.x the State of the Reject Force Hook for the repositories is not retained.  It will be off for all repositories regardless of its previous state before the upgrade.

h3. HTR
# Setup Stash 3.x and enable Reject Force Push in the repositories Hooks settings
# Upgrade to 4.x.x

h3. Expected results
The Reject Force Push hook is still enabled.

h3. Actual results
Note the state of the Reject Force Push is disabled

h3. Analysis
The hook keys retain their old namespace reference to "com.atlassian.stash.stash-bundled-hooks" which doesn't match the new namespace "com.atlassian.bitbucket.server.bitbucket-bundled-hooks".

h3. Workaround

{panel:|bgColor=#FFFFCE}(!) Always back up your database before performing any modification to the database. If possible, try your modifications on a test server.{panel}
Perform a database update:
{code:title=Postgres SQL to change state of Reject Force Push Hook to state that it was in before upgrade}
UPDATE public.sta_repo_hook
SET hook_key = 'com.atlassian.bitbucket.server.bitbucket-bundled-hooks:force-push-hook' 
WHERE hook_key = 'com.atlassian.stash.stash-bundled-hooks:force-push-hook'
AND repository_id NOT IN (
    SELECT repository_id
    FROM public.sta_repo_hook
    WHERE hook_key = 'com.atlassian.bitbucket.server.bitbucket-bundled-hooks:force-push-hook'
)
{code}
fields.summary: Upgrade to Bitbucket Server 4.x from Stash 3.x results in Reject Force Push HOOK being disabled. Config breaks with plugin-key rename from stash to bitbucket namespace

fields.description:
In our instance of Bitbucket Server 4.1.3 connected to Crowd, two users are a member of the same project which contains server repositories. In the commit listing of one repository, the name of user that originally did the commits (let's call it 'User 1') was replaced by the name of another user (let's call it 'User 2'). Upon a little research we noticed that both users, both present in the Crowd instance to which Bitbucket is linked, have the same email address (let's say 'user@domain.com'). One user is in the corporate AD, the other in the Crowd Internal directory. The commits were done from a Git client in which the user's email address was configured as users@domain.com.

Analysis: Apparently Bitbucket looks up the user belonging to a commit using the email address found in the commit log, and fails to detect that more than one user with the same email address may be present in the user directory. This resulted in displaying the wrong user in the commit listing in the Bitbucket UI.

Impact: This bug caused confusion for my colleague and may also lead to wrong conclusions from auditors regarding users access if it accidentally happens, e.g. when a user with read-only access is displayed as committer instead of (the correct) user with read-write access.

Workaround:
- Change the email address of user2 in Crowd Internal directory to something other than that of user1 in the corporate AD
- Synchronize the external user directory in Bitbucket 
- Refresh the commit listing
fields.summary: Wrong user shown in commit listing due to duplicate email address in Crowd

fields.description:
h3. Problem Definition

When many branch permissions exist for _specific branches_ (not "Pattern" or "Branch model" type permissions), the branch permissions page can take a long time to load.

The reason for this is that Bitbucket Server will resolve the ref for the branch the permission applies to, in order to determine the display name of the ref, and it's availability. 

h3. Workaround 

To work around this issue, use "Pattern" permissions instead of "Branch" permissions. 
You can qualify your pattern to ensure it will only match **branches**, for example: 

* the pattern {{heads/master}} will match any branch called {{master}}
* the pattern {{master}} will match any branch _or tag_ called {{master}}

For more information on patterns see [the documentation on branch permission patterns|https://confluence.atlassian.com/bitbucketserver/branch-permission-patterns-776639814.html].
fields.summary: Improve page load time of branch permissions page

fields.description:
With the addition of the Dev Panel, it seems that Bitbucket doesn't send anymore responses to the Source Tab if a Fisheye integration is still present. Instead it leaves an error message within the Source Tab above the Fisheye information as such: {code}This list may be incomplete, as errors occurred whilst retrieving source from linked applications:
Request to http://<stash-url>:<port> failed: Failed to parse the response from Stash: null{code}

However, the Development Panel works fine as suspected.

*Steps to test:*
# Created AppLink between JIRA 6.4.5 and Bitbucket Server 4.0.3.
# I had an AppLink already created to a FishEye instance - so I had the Source and Reviews tabs showing up in a JIRA issue.
# Committed something to my Bitbucket repo, referencing a JIRA issue created for testing.

*Results*
Development Panel works fine, but the Source tab shows a "null" result when trying to get information from Bitbucket.


*Additional Info:*
Fisheye was only mentioned because that's the only way we found the Source tab to be present.


*Resolution*
Support for Bitbucket Server was added in JIRA FishEye Plugin 6.3.10. JIRA 6.3.x and 6.4.x users can get the upgrade either:
# Downloading it from [Marketplace|https://marketplace.atlassian.com/plugins/com.atlassian.jirafisheyeplugin].
# Or using the 'upgrade' functionality on the 'Manage add-ons' page.
fields.summary: Upgrade JIRA FishEye Plugin (JFP) to support Bitbucket Server

fields.description:
The pull requests panel shows two tabs: Reviewing and Created. Once you have approved a pull request it becomes harder to find again. You need to navigate to each project you might have a pull request open for, and look through all of the open pull requests there.

It would be great if we had a third tab to show Approved pull requests that haven't been merged yet. This way if we want to wait for a second approval we don't lose track of the pull requests we're responsible for.

Thanks!
fields.summary: Ability to See Approved Pull Requests in PR Panel

fields.description:
Currently when [splitting a repository | https://confluence.atlassian.com/bitbucket/split-a-repository-in-two-313464964.html#Splitarepositoryintwo-UsingGittosplit-outadirectory], the PR history is lost because it is tied to the old repository, and those commits are no longer available.

Please provide a safe method for splitting repositories while maintaining PR histories, such as a "Split Repository" button which would prompt for a name for the new repository and the filter parameters, and then update the database to match the commits in both new repositories.
fields.summary: Split Repository with PR History

fields.description:
Plugins which use a {{<scope>import</scope>}} for the {{com.atlassian.bitbucket.server:bitbucket-parent}} POM and have dependencies on certain modules, like {{bitbucket-spi}}, end up unexpectedly bundling {{commons-lang:commons-lang}}.

In {{bitbucket-parent}}, the {{commons-lang:commons-lang}} entry in {{<dependencyManagement/>}} has an explicit {{<scope>runtime</scope>}} applied. When {{commons-lang}} is pulled in transitively via a {{<scope>provided</scope>}} dependency, that explicit "runtime" ends up overriding the "provided" scope. As a result, {{commons-lang}} is bundled in the plugin.
fields.summary: Plugins built with some Bitbucket Server dependencies unexpectedly bundle commons-lang

# Fork a repo to your personal project.
# Open a PR from your fork to the upstream repo.
# Delete your fork.

The PR ref lozenge will display your fork name and branch.

h4. Actual Result
The PR ref lozenge just displays the branch.
fields.summary: Persist repo name in PR ref source lozenge even after fork is deleted

fields.description:
As a Stash/Bitbucket Server User I want to be able to delete my personal fork even though I have a pull request (open OR declined) to an upstream repo to which I no longer have permission to access.
h4. HTR
 # Fork a repo to your personal project.
 # Open a PR from your fork to the upstream repo.
 # Have a user with Project Admin or higher perms remove your permission to the upstream repo.
 # Push another change to your personal fork that would update the PR (the PR shouldn't be visible to you anymore at this point).
 # Delete your fork.

h4. Expected Result

My forked repo is deleted successfully.
h4. Actual Result

Fork deletion fails and an error modal is displayed:
 !2015-12-11_1631.png|thumbnail!
{quote}Repository deletion was canceled.
 Pull requests involving ~DROHAN/blues could not be cleaned up. The repository may not be delete
{quote}
fields.summary: Cross-repository pull requests prevent deletion of personal forks in some cases

        at org.apache.felix.framework.BundleWiringImpl.findClassOrResourceByDelegation(BundleWiringImpl.java:1494) ~[org.apache.felix.framework-4.2.1.jar:na]
        ... 41 common frames omitted
{noformat}
 
h3. Notes

The class that is the subject of all your {{ClassNotFoundException}}'s - {{com.atlassian.devstatus.vcs.LimitExceededEvent}} - isn't part of Bitbucket core or any bundled plugin and hasn't been for a very long time.  It used to be part of a bundled plugin called the {{atlassian-dev-status-plugin}}, but this was removed from Stash 3.1 and replaced with another plugin called the {{atlassian-remote-event-producer-plugin}} that doesn't export any {{LimitExceededEvent}} class. 

The context of the {{ClassNotFoundException}} seems to indicate it was thrown inside of an event handler, possibly in a plugin, but the stack for this is gone as the exception isn't caught until it gets to {{SingleParameterMethodListenerInvoker}} (which is where in fact the {{LimitExceededEvent}} class loading error is reported). 


h3.Solution
{{atlassian-dev-status}} plugin, Perform a search on your file system of our server and and you should find an old {{atlassian-dev-status-api-2.5.9.jar}} in OSGI cache directory. 

The problem should be solved by cleaning the cache directory:
# Shutdown Bitbucket Server.
# Backup and remove the following directories. They will be rebuilt when Stash starts again:
#* {{$BITBUCKET_HOME/plugins/.bundled-plugins/}}
#* {{$BITBUCKET_HOME/plugins/.osgi-cache/}}
# Restart Bitbucket Server.
fields.summary: No events transitioned to JIRA due to java.lang.NoClassDefFoundError: com/atlassian/devstatus/vcs/LimitExceededEvent

fields.description:
h3. Problem Definition

After a user creates a Pull Request and a different user edits it, browsing through its Pull Request list seems to show the user who last updated it incorrectly.

In the example below, you can see that "Administrator" _seems to be_ the user who last updated it whereas in fact, this represents the user who _created_ the Pull Request. We never show the user that updated the PR but only the date in which that was last updated.
!PR.png|thumbnail!

The information that follows the comma shows when the PR owned by "Administrator" was last updated.

h3. Suggested Solution

The fix here is a design one. The representation with a comma causes confusion at times. We should make it clearer that "Administrator" is the owner of the PR.
 
h3. Workaround 

There is no workaround for this issue.
fields.summary: PR List design update - separate author name from "last modified date"

fields.description:
{panel:title=Atlassian status as of March 2020|borderStyle=solid|borderColor=#deebff|titleBGColor=#deebff|bgColor=#ffffff}
Hi all,

I'm excited to share that in Bitbucket Server 7.0 we shipped redesigned and optimized pull request page with several improvements you’ve been asking us, including more efficient use of the screen space in side-by-side diff.

You can find more information in the Bitbucket Server 7.0 [release notes|https://confluence.atlassian.com/bitbucketserver/bitbucket-server-7-0-release-notes-990546638.html] and Pull Requests [documentation|https://confluence.atlassian.com/bitbucketserver/review-and-discuss-a-pull-request-808488540.html].

Please, don't hesitate to leave feedback on the feature in the comments. This will help us to priorities further development.

Anton Genkin
Product Manager Bitbucket Server
{panel} 

*Original message*

The Bitbucket-diff tool has a very inefficient layout. This means on my screen (a standard 3:4 screen) that I only have 50 characters per side-by-side file. This too less to be able to do a reasonable review.

Inefficiencies are pointed out in the attached image:
 - Lots of superfluous whitespace. Many margins can be reduced. There seems to be a default reservation for files up to 999999 lines, but smaller files do not that that much room for line numbers
 - The list of tiles subject of change is on the left. You must collapse that panel to have a screen that has enough usable space. But if you collapse it, it takes up too much space. since the information in collapsed state is zero. There also is no need to have that panel, since the information already is on top of the diff view.

!20151106_diffs-annotated.jpg|thumbnail!

As an example; Reviewboard has a more pragmatic representation, showing the file list on top and all changed files below. That also has the advantage that you can scroll through a diff instead of constantly having to switch between files manually.
fields.summary: Improve efficiency of layout for the diff-tool

fields.description:
The server-side soy template 'bitbucket.internal.widget.avatar' provides a very simple but useful component. It:
* Accepts a Person, being either an ApplicationUser or a SimplePerson
* For an ApplicationUser, will find their avatar within Bitbucket Server
* For a SimplePerson, will attempt to find a Gravatar URL for the email address
* Generates the ADG-compliant AUI elements

This may not sound too hard, however Bitbucket developer Felix Haehnel has shown that it takes quite a bit of legwork within a plugin to pull all this together.
https://bitbucket.org/fhaehnel/avatar-list-plugin-sample/src/03d6a1c5e3d6?at=master

All that work, just to render the same avatars that Bitbucket renders for users. Compared to that, using the soy template is a breeze.

Please make it public! :)
fields.summary: Make the 'bitbucket.internal.widget.avatar' soy template a public API

fields.description:
h4. Problem
The way git works when it comes to file history is that entries returned are likely to be simplified, so that changes that even each other out are not displayed. As from the [git documentation|https://www.kernel.org/pub/software/scm/git/docs/git-log.html]:
{quote}Simplifies the history to the simplest history explaining the final state of the tree. Simplest because it prunes some side branches if the end result is the same (i.e. merging branches with the same content){quote}

Bitbucket Server relies on the default git behavior concerning history simplification, resulting in some history entries being omitted when looking at file history. A possible scenario, when you modify a file in a commit, then afterwards merge a branch that has the earlier version of the same file. In such a case, neither the original commit, nor the merge commit are shown in the file's history, as the sum of the changes results in the same file.

h4. Workaround
To see the complete history of the file, use the following command in the git repository on disk, using git command line client:
{{git log --full-history --graph -- <path-to-file>}}

h4. Suggestion
Provide an option to see the "full history" of files in some way. Possible solutions may include, providing this as a per-user, per-repository or per-project setting or simply have a {{Show full history}} button when viewing file history. An indication of omitted history entries would be beneficial in that case.
fields.summary: Option to show full history for files

fields.description:
1) In the diff view, the tree pane often expands more than needed an leaving little space for the diff pane.
Wanted behavior: Click-n-drag possibility on the border between tree and source panes to select how wide the tree-pane should be. But, keeping the auto hide feature (which is nice)

2) When opening the diff tab for a PullRequest and using the side-by-side diff the page is scrolled to the first diff. Whn I want to see the header for the PullRequest, I have to scroll a lot to get to the top.
Wanted behavior: Allowing me to 
* scroll the source tree (much shorter scroll to the top) when mouse is hovering the source tree
* scroll the source diff when hovering the source diff
fields.summary: Diff tab usability enhancements

fields.description: Currently if a pull request is submitted and a merge is done before all the reviewers have approved the changes, any reviewers who look at the changes after the merge cannot submit an approval. I believe the reviewer can still add comments, but I don’t believe they can check the approve box. I would like to allow approvals after merges to at least allow the reviewer to say that he has looked over the changes that were already merged.
fields.summary: As a Stash user, I want to be able to approve a pull request after it has been merged

h4. Steps to reproduce

fields.description:
h3. Problem Definition

The pull request list page shows comment counts for each pull request, but it does not give any more information about who or when. More specifically, it doesn't show if any comments have been made after the latest code change on the pull request.

It would be useful to be able to use the list of pull requests to get an overview of whether they need attention specifically for the logged in user. Currently you cannot determine the latest action, only being able to see if I the user is involved in them.

h3. Suggested Solution
 
Create another filter for the list page (similar to "I'm reviewing") to highlight pull requests that have been updated and require attention from the logged in user, for example "Needs my attention"
fields.summary: A way to identify updated pull requests (from the user's perspective) on the pull request list page

fields.description:
h3. Problem
When deleting a user directory the entire instance will lock up, all requests will wait forever.

This is caused by a database deadlock in crowd which blocks all calls to things that do things like find the current authenticated user.

h3. Affected Environments
Evaluation users using HSQL or H2 where table level locking is used.

Cannot reproduce on 4.2-rc7 So changes in the crowd code since 3.11 may have reduced or eliminated the chances of this error occurring.

h3. Workaround
# Restart the instance.
# Upgrade to [one of the supported production databases|https://confluence.atlassian.com/display/BitbucketServer/Supported+platforms#Supportedplatforms-databasesDatabases]. H2 and HSQLDB are for evaluation purposes only.
fields.summary: Database deadlock while deleting a user directory using H2 or HSQLDB

fields.description:
h4. Requirement
Provide the option for Bitbucket Server to send HipChat notifications when a build finishes. Currently administrators have the option to directly hook up Bamboo or Jenkins with HipChat to get such notifications, but it would be convenient to have a single point of integration for such notifications.

h4. Workaround
Currently administrators can configure HipChat notifications from [Bamboo|https://confluence.atlassian.com/bamboo/integrating-bamboo-with-hipchat-289276960.html] or [Jenkins|https://wiki.jenkins-ci.org/display/JENKINS/HipChat+Plugin] directly.
fields.summary: HipChat notification for builds

fields.description:
An application that accepts serialized objects and deserializes the objects without performing appropriate validation is susceptible to remote execution vulnerabilities.  This is a common weakness described in "CWE-502: Deserialization of Untrusted Data" (http://cwe.mitre.org/data/definitions/502.html) and is applicable across multiple platforms, including Java.
In January and November 2015, information was published that demonstrated how this vulnerability can be exploited using the Apache Commons Collections libraries, v3.2.1 and v4.0.  

Solution Background
Object serialization is widely used on platforms such as Java and is even the centerpiece of Java technologies like RMI, EJB, RMX, etc.  The root cause of the problem is that if there is any object reachable from your runtime that declares itself serializable and could be fooled into doing something bad by malicious data, then it can be exploited through deserialization.  Applications must never deserialize untrusted data.

For details, see Vulnerability Note VU#576313: Apache Commons Collections Java library insecurely deserializes data (http://www.kb.cert.org/vuls/id/576313).

All applications that package Apache commons collections must be updated to use v3.3.2 (released) or v4.1 (not yet released, as of this writing).
fields.summary: Security vulnerability in apache commons collections

fields.description:
h3. Summary

Deleting a repository with a large number of indexed commits (i.e. commits referencing a JIRA issue) results in the following message on Bitbucket Server UI:
{noformat}
Server Unreachable – The server didn't respond. You may retry your request when the server comes back up.
{noformat}

!ErrorServerUnreachable.png|thumbnail!

h3. Environment
Bitbucket server installed with the default embedded H2 in-memory database

h3. Steps to Reproduce
# Install Bitbucket server
# Use the default H2 in-memory database
# Create a repository with a large amount of JIRA issues indexed (e.g.: 40,000)
# Delete the repository

h3. Expected Results
The repository gets deleted and a success message is shown on the UI.

h3. Actual Results
The repository is deleted but the following message is displayed on the UI:
{noformat}
Server Unreachable – The server didn't respond. You may retry your request when the server comes back up.
{noformat} 

h3. Notes
The problem observed here occurs because the deletion of the repository is slow to happen on the database side. 

Because the deletion involves a series of {{cascade}} deletes which H2 is taking too long to apply.

h3.Workaround
No workaround is required as the action is performed successfully.
fields.summary: Repository deletion times out

fields.description:
The dependency on Apache Commons Collections should be upgraded to v.3.2.2 to incorporate the fix for: [COLLECTIONS-580 - Arbitrary remote code execution with InvokerTransformer|https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/COLLECTIONS-580]

There is no known exploit for this vulnerability in Bitbucket Server or Bitbucket Data Centre, however this library should be upgraded regardless.
fields.summary: Update Apache Commons Collections to v3.2.2
